comments.commentBody: Politics is essentially secular in nature, nothing inherently moral or immoral about it, for at its core, it's meant to serve social purpose. it's up to the people how they perceive it, and practise it.

Ah, Profressor, professional politicians have ALWAYS lacked autonomy of decision making, whether they are enslaved by money interests or by the need to grant favors to multitudes of the shirtless for votes to retain their dependent power.

You affect cynicism today, but you're insufficienly cynical by much. Politics is neither the "art of the possible", nor the application of "social vision", as you argue; but the sausage-making of interest, when the interest is securing and retaining power.

Whyever do you suppose we place professional politicians in our regard below liability and divorce lawyers, two other forms of related life the world could well do without? Except that we'd just re-invent all three in order to have something to detest and loathe more than we do the digger-wasp, whose male and female variants infect a third variant with their seed, which eats the host alive as it gestates.

Too MUCH cynicism? Hardly.
Not cynicism really, Richard, you and me are looking at politics from different prisms.

Politics being central to society, there could never be any anti-political moment in life, as David Brooks seems to believe. So is his belief that the present generation detests politics. For, the Machiavellian dilemma of reconciling noble purpose with low cunning seems to have always persisted ever since the state and organised society made their appearance on the earth. However, if politics appears different from its basic nature today, and evokes disliking and distrust of new generation, it's because the practitioners of politics have not only lost social vision, but also their autonomy of decision making to serve the larger public good, while willingly turning to be puppets to the powerful special interest groups. It's this loss of self command and blurring of social vision that seems to have distorted the real meaning of politics, turning it ugly and filthy.
How do you know what other people read?

Most of the ``arguments'' given against the theory of evolution pretend that they are opposing one ``biological idea'' only. In reality they are opposing all of physics (big bang) and chemistry (``the deluge changed everything and our measurments of geological time are wrong.'') It is this  - that the creationists are up against all of science, not just one ``small'' theory that has to be heavily propagandized in the coming years to clear up the anti-intellectual climate in the US

I don't entertain people "who reject geological time." Wouldn't be caught dead in their company. I wonder if they'd go for "The Last Testament: A Memoir" by God* or The Jefferson Bible, "The Life and Morals of Jesus of Nazareth" ** as it is formally titled?

As far as Jefferson was concerned, "It would be very nice if there were a God who created the world and was a benevolent providence, and if there were a moral order in the universe and an after-life; but it is a very striking fact that all this is exactly as we are bound to wish it to be."

How Evangelical is THAT!

* http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/28/books/the-last-testament-a-memoir-by-g...
** http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_Bible

I have friends who reject geological time and think the Grand Canyon is a result of Noah's flood. Of course they wouldn't be caught reading liberal stuff like the Oxford Annotated Bible and certainly wouldn't read "The Rocks Don't Lie: A Geologist Investigates Noah's Flood" by David Montgomery, a well-reviewed recent book.

I suspect that geological time is hard to grasp, and it's comforting to snuggle up to conservative nostrums like gold as money, Thomas Jefferson as a devout Evangelical Christian, and the necessity of cutting Medicaid expenditures on poor children (which Florida is doing, viciously).

Good thing for the Niners that they have two good QBs.  In the violent world of the NFL, it's hard to get through a season without your #1 going down with an injury.  QB controvery?  As both guys said, get over it and be a team player.
Rubio would probably insist that the time-lapse photography in "Chasing Ice" had been faked.  In any case he's too busy chasing votes.

Menachem Begin, a leader of the Irgun, was identified as a terrorist by the British, who took over the occupation of Israel/ Palestine/Whatever following the occupation by the Turks, who took over the occupation.... The people who suffer are the ones who have been living there since the time of the Canaanites, who were occupied by the Jews, who were occupied by the Babylonians, who were occupied....

This is not a circumstance that is somehow unique to this little strip of land along the Eastern coast of the mediterranean, it is the history of our species (just ask the Sioux on the Pine Ridge reservation, or the Serbians in Croatia, or...). We either learn to live together, or we continue to die together. The king of the hill today, will be the 90 pound weakling of tomorrow.........

It is up to each of us to oppose aggression. But you are probably just like me. Too busy living my life here in the land of the Free, paying taxes into the biggest war/death machine the world has ever known, to take any real stand beyond some empty words on some silly blog online!

Maybe our childrens, childrens, children..... will know a world without war. But I fear it is much more likely that there will be a world that does not know our children.

Rima, I hope you're right about Bibi being capable of seizing the moment, but I have my doubts.  He's certainly shown very little capacity for that kind of statesmanship so far.  As for Meshal being ready to talk, how would we know?  Even though he was duly elected by his people, the US and Israel pronounced Hamas a "terrorist" organization and refused to negotiate with them, preferring instead to give them "freedom" inside a giant prison camp isolated from the outside world.  Hamas won those elections because besides being a "terrorist" group opposed to the existence of Israel, they were also pretty good at helping local communities with food, medicine and governance.  One man's terrorist is another man's Freedom Fighter.  The Israelis refused to talk to the PLO for years and things went nowhere, while they started building "facts on the ground," and annexed Jerusalem. In an underreported story (IMHO) the Israelis destroyed for the second time, the Soccer Stadium in Gaza.  One little shred of hope and pride they had.  Now why do you think that was targeted?  Twice.  The Palestinians have been given a raw deal from day 1.  They have lived in poverty and squalor for 60 years under the gun.  They were offered a swiss-cheese Bantustan as a settlement which Arafat rightly turned down.  As distasteful as Bibi and HIllary may find it, we need to talk to Hamas.

In order to bring about the kind of change you write about, not only do both sides need to evolve along the same path, but so do all those in the periphery.Culturally, this kind of metamorphosis seems unlikely in what remains of my lifetime.

The Israel of Ben Gurion, Golda Meir, and Menachem Begin was changed, hardened by Arik Sharon and the Lebanon war. The labor party of Tzipi Livni is not in power and likely won't be, this election cycle. Bibi Netanyahu is no Menachem Begin, but like him, I believe he is capable of seizing the moment and forging ahead with peace, should the Palestinians decide they're ready. It doesn't look to me like Meshal is either ready to talk, or willing to accept that Israel is here to stay. When it comes to it, I suspect Meshal is about twenty years behind, in his thinking, where Yassir Arafat was before his death. Sadly, that's very far behind.

You mirror my initial and subsequent reactions pretty closely, Laszlo.  I think it's part of Patrick Berry's genius that he can craft a puzzle that is fairly easy and smooth, but altogether elegant at the same time.  The entries are accessible without being hackneyed, and the clues are fresh and entertaining.  This puzzle wasn't challenging in the sense of making me try to dredge up memories or work out third-degree connections, but it tickled my brain and made me think in a fun way.
Wasn't there a fairly recent puzzle with CHICHI CHIHUAHUA? Had a theme of a 3-syllable/ 2-syllable repeat...

I hope everyone enjoyed (survived?) their Thanksgiving feast.

When I saw Patrick Berry’s name, I expected a tough but fair, and expertly crafted puzzle. Everything was as I expected, except the part about it being tough. I found it a little easier than most of his, or maybe the few clues in my wheelhouse made it an easier fill for me than normal.

Maybe Patrick and Will made this a “Friday Lite” on purpose, knowing full well that overeating dulls the brain. They were right, I just got lucky.

I was surprised to learn that CHIHUAHUA was a debut entry among the total 14 debuts today. That is amazing. This is why Patrick Barry is one of my favorite constructors.

The only entry I wasn’t crazy about was ATALOWEBB, but DAYMARE more than made up for it. Thank you Patrick and Will for this satisfying, wonderful Black Friday gift.

I agree with Liz about the media.  Their modus operandi seems to be to create polarities, regardless of the weight of each side.   I remember Tom Cruiz' negation of Brooks Shield's book on her experience with postpartum depression, because of his Scientology doctrine, with debunks all psychiatry.  She responded with an excellent Op Ed in the NYT.  The Associated Press kept it going by interviewing John Travolta's wife, another Scientologist, to refute what Shield's wrote.  Postpartum depression is a serious disease.  It should not be treated as a celebrity boxing match. This was a serious disservice to those who suffer from postpartum depression and may well have kept people from getting much needed treatment.

Reply to comment by "Keynes": It's irresponsible to say that debt doesn't matter, as Dick Cheney did. The real Keynes didn't day that. He said, and what Clinton/Gore set us on a path to do, pay down debt after the economy returns to prosperity.

Bush 2 set that low bar for intellectual curiosity, that's what gets you Iraq and a financial meltdown.  After the Rominees performance I am beginning to think that Harvard Business School specializes in crushing intellectual curiosity.

Not only conservative or religious heads are firmly emplanted in the sand. Most of the political and economic community as well as the press and general population of the country adhere to a knowledge of finance that stopped being germane when Nixon took us off the gold standard in 1971. They believe the federal government is no different from a state or houshold in terms of it's need to tighten it's belt when times are lean, when the exact opposite is true. They still think that banks can only make loans after they take deposits, when in fact they make loans and then adjust reserves after the fact. They think the government will go bankrupt if the budget isn't balanced, whereas it can never go bankrupt unless the Congress passes a law limiting its ability to run a deficit. From the President, the Congress, to Simpson and Bowles and the Peter Peterson foundation they preach austerity when the opposite is needed to create demand which will restore employment, GDP growth, and fill the tax coffers. This thinking is also a form of faith and anti-science that is not limited to people who are religious or conservative. It is just a form of intellectual laziness in not learning that since 1971 our country is operating on a different set of financial rules than before.

what I feel is such measures would only add the dissatisfaction in employees. Just by stopping these sites doesn't guarantee an increase in focus/efficiency but would surely provide negativity to the brand image.

A frequent France visitor admitted not seeing the Louvre, explaining that once he visited there might not be another strong reason to return, so he would tour the country first and save the fabled museum for last... I am saving "Lincoln" after finishing Sandburg's (very soon).  This wondrous Sesquicentennial.
The movie 'Lincoln' is worth the time and the money. I highly recommend it for persons with a strong grasp of the period and also those who don't.

It's not just the standards, Walter, it's the expectations of the education system of kids, based on race. This abomination wasn't adopted in those two states only, but also in Georgia and is being considered in others. Governor Jindal's education policies in Louisiana have gone largely unnoticed in the noise of the election season.

Education, how it is approached, in all its permutations, urgently needs thorough scrutiny at the Federal level.

Dear Sir/Madam,

The outburst of Lawyer Karuna Nudy here is nothing but myopic and self serving, she can't comprehand the rational of "Section 66A of the Information Technology Act of 2008", in broader context and beyond this case - I am aghast.

It is very important for India to have such broad laws.

Just a few months back we had very serious trouble in the North Eastern Indian state of Assam, where there were riots involving local tribal Bodos and Bangladeshi illigal aliens. A lot of people were killed, several hundred thousand displaced, millions of $ worth of propery destroyed.

Subsequntly, there was a mass exodus of people of North East from South of India, because someone there made a threatening FB post, promising revenge by Muslims on a certain day against people of N.E. Needles to say, it went viral. 100,000+ N.E. people fled Southern city of Hyderabad, Banglore & Chennai. The culprit(s) were apprehanded, but the damage was done. Paklistani miscreants played no lesser role sending doctored photos to inflame the situation.

The above incident proves that Absolute & ungoverned Freedom of speech on Social media in Indian Subcontinent is as dangerous as letting immatures play with an AK-47 with safety letch off, one irresponsible post/action & it could spell very serious trouble. A lot of people could get hurt or even die.

Is Absolute Freedom of Expression, worth someone's life? Heck NO. Shaheen was lucky to have escaped only with an apology.
Way to go maam . :-)

Why does anybody want to see anyone else in a particular way? Its one thing to discuss personal preferences, but it shows narrow-mindedness if one is going to force one's preferences (even if they are good) upon others.

Apart from sometimes misconstrued statements one has to look at a larger picture here, right?
It is not Americanization, but voice of Young India how they want to see their revered teachers in the
Class rooms. India is one of the World’s largest democracies and this is the best example of that ,when
teachers , ‘Brave Hearts’ allow kids to share their views. How many have the so called courage to invite
criticisms? Very few.
Now what has been conveniently omitted is; kids also mentioned how they revere teachers and accept
them any way they are! Bravo to kids who not only have immense respect for teachers but also think
that their opinion matters! Bravo to teachers who are open to redefinition of professional grooming and
thoughts of learners!
Bravo to DPS for allowing this session which no other institution would ever have the mettle to
Conceive! Teachers of DPS Bangalore South are always well dressed and these were just views of kids
how they want to see and not want see their teachers. Kavita Ghosh ( A Proud faculty member of DPS
Bangalorore)
We cyclists wear balaclavas in the old weather. If there is a group ride and most of us were wearing one, would we be breaking the law?
What they would probably do is tell us to read our Bibles more, and stop women from getting abortions and gays from getting married.  Then God would step in an fix the climate.

Philosophy is among the missing ingredients in our education system. Were it to be taught, as early as first grade, we would be giving our kids a well-rounded education that promotes excellent critical-thinking skills and encourages natural curiosity.

The right has been using religion as a means to control education in general, and science in particular, in order to change back the clock on certain societal changes it didn't agree with. Attempting to enact personhood laws that set conception at two weeks before sex, is one example. Enacting laws that make a zygote a sentient human being at conception, is another example.

Science and religion don't need to be at odds with each other. Ethics, when there is a question of propriety, is what keeps science on the right path - not religion, even though religion does come with sets of ethics for certain things.

I just read Gaza without end: You explicitly lay out exactly the cycle I described in this comment.

"As usual, the prelude was messy — a rocket fired from Gaza hitting southern Israel on Nov. 3; a Palestinian killed near the border on Nov. 4; three Israeli soldiers wounded in a blast at the border on Nov. 6; a Palestinian boy killed by Israeli machine-gun fire on Nov. 8; four Israelis soldiers wounded by an anti-tank missile on Nov. 10; four Palestinian teenagers killed when Israel fires back; steadily increasing rocket fire from Gaza. (That is just a rough summary, and of course each side has a different version.)" http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/20/opinion/roger-cohen-Gaza-Without-End.h...

Independent actions by palestinians, coupled with clouded judgements by the Israeli military, escalated into poor Israeli military-political decisions.

So why write this article? I don't understand. You clearly can see how the cycle works: why is your solution then to simply have society call for an abandoning of hatred when you know that won't prevent this cycle of violence?

Why not argue for alternative and better ways for Palestinians and Israelis to channel that hatred and resentment? Maybe you can undermine the cycle by eliminating the draft and/or incorporating careful military training against this resentment. Then again, maybe this was just an emotional overflow, and "talk it out" and "give up hatred" weren't intended as solutions at all.

People who have very little to lose tend to hang on to hatred. Gaza is a very harsh, very poor place to live. Make it a decent place to live, with infrastructure and jobs, and people, especially the young, will have less reason to be angry and hate.

Lincoln would indeed have approved.  I believe that in the midst of the festivities when the surrender of Lee at Appomattox was announced, Lincoln requested that the band play "Dixie," remarking something like "I always liked that tune."

One might conclude that flying the Confederate flag is about honoring one's heritage, but a black man being passed by that pickup truck on the road might come to a different conclusion.  It's a bit of a stretch to imagine that Lincoln would have approved, given the loss of life in a battle over the enslavement of human beings.  But I suppose you could find some who would approve.  David Duke comes to mind.

Gus:

Actually, it depends on the school. Lincoln's primary priority always was preservation of the union, and we shouldn't need recourse to a Spielberg flick to know that. But, lest African Americans think less of him for that, he also was perhaps the most vocal white man of his times to volubly decry the notion that some should live by the compelled sweat of the many; and he stated this conviction early and throughout his life; and, in the end, he was the single irreplaceable force that ended it.

Stephen Spielberg owes you one. I had decided to go see the movie and had not yet and now will not miss it. Thank you David; your many talents now include a movie review from the heart.

The subject has been near and dear to me since I was a very young boy and began to realize the great challenges President Lincoln had faced. Later tracing his steps as it were from Gettysburg to the other battlefields and to the magnificence of the outstanding tribute and memorial in Washington, DC, it is clear that he is still the once in an era political figure which some nations produce who live to inspire people worldwide.

His character which you discuss and his foresight were the high lights for me and continue to be. His nobility and the agonies of decisions he wrestled with, made or tarried on, which affected so many lives and deaths, are even today consequential.

Reconciliation is a slow and agonizing process and now a 150 years on in time from his era there are signs of maturity in unlikely places. Very recently, on a country road, way below the Mason Dixon line in Delaware a pickup truck passed me flying two full sized flags just aft of the cab; on the drivers side a Stars and Bars and on the right side the Stars and Stripes. The young man waved as he went by. My conclusion is that he honored his heritage, his present and his future all at the same time. I think that President Abraham Lincoln would have approved.

Alcohol just not just kill thousands of citizens, it has and always will destroy families.

And yet, a person can drink themselves into a stupor every night for less than $5 a day.

Before I give a synopsis of a rather spectacular marijuana fueled crime, let me state that I voted for legalization in Washington upon the principal that keeping it illegal created more harm than legalizing it. That harm is measured by all the nasty crimes related to its production and distribution. They, it seems to me, outweigh the harm done outside of that.

However, Maryjane is not a harmless drug. Some of you may remember a crime that happened in Florida over the summer. A man was shot dead by a policeman after attacking a homeless man. The attacker—likely disturbed to begin with—chewed off a good part of the homeless man's face and blinded him. When confronted by the policeman, he "growled" at the officer, who shot him several times before he stopped.

Now, awful as that is, such crimes are rare. We lifted prohibition because keeping alcohol illegal outweighed in its harm making it legal.
Thor, the man wasn't high on weed, but "bath salts", something else altogether.

'From his years as a community organizer — and a young man whose own recreational drug use could have made him just another number in lockup — Obama knows well that racial minorities are disproportionately jailed for these crimes.'

Imagine if our now President Obama had been caught doing recreational use of marijuana in one of those less than tolerant states, and gotten some jail time? There likely never would have been a president named Obama.

The voters of Washington and Colorado states have sent a clear signal to those empowered with making decisions. Stop criminalizing innocent behavior. From what I have read, there has not been a death caused by smoking or ingestion of marijuana, unlike alcohol which kills thousands each year.

Finally sanity has come to many of the states of the union, with accepted use of medical marijuana, and now two states leading the way toward decriminalization for all. Let us hope that the federal government under our President's leadership, will dismantle the machinery for prosecution and persecution of casual marijuana users. Just remember your own history, Mr. Obama.

Apparently "Starve the Beast" program hasn't worked so far to reduce spending, as a percentage of GDP, though spending on social programs and subsidizing cash-strapped states suffered greatly with worsening misery for the poor and needy.

As Mr. Bartlett has advocated elsewhere, the Bush tax cuts should be allowed to expire. But I would suggest, to keep them for the bottom 60%, not 98% of taxpayers. The bottom 60% of taxpayers' contribution to the entire individual federal income tax is only a little over 10%, as their taxable incomes are around $50,000 and less. The other 40% may experience a little pain, but that pain is necessary for the common good, and could be made temporary, as the state income tax increase in CA through proposition 30.

It would be quite desirable to have another tax bracket of 50% on >$5 million, and still another of 70% on >$25 million. A "blessing" in disguise for the 70% taxpayers is that they would be far less tempted to operate at the edges of law, with less chance to end up in prison.

Tax expenditures should be reduced, without hurting the lower income groups: Capital gains tax should be raised to 25%; dividends >$10,000 and hedge fund managers incomes should be treated as ordinary incomes, as so on. All these would add around $6 trillion to the revenue in ten years, enough to balance the budget by then, if not earlier, I believe, and will still have enough money for a second stimulus, most of which would pay for itself, eventually.
the author's intent was not the article you wanted to read, so write your own then.

Now I am living in Japan and I actually see lots of foreigners working in stores and restaurants.Most of them seem to be Chinese or Koreans.They really work hard and speak Japanese fluently.I don't know whether japanese people can work in other countries like them.We Japanese really need to overcome our shyness in various situations.

While I agree with the sentiment about the need for Hun Sen to have a conscious and reflect on his choices, the exaltation of Theary Sang and the "perfect justice or no justice" crowd in this article is unfortunate. First, Theary Sang, I am afraid, has used the ECCC/Khmer Rouge tribunal as a way to put the spotlight on her, especially during her unprofessional civil party representation. Furthermore, this idea that international justice can overnight develop into a system able to investigate and prosecute ALL the most powerful individuals in the world is unrealistic and not helping anyone. It takes time, patience and persistent. Trying to undermine the system as is, while in its infancy, is counterproductive and juvenile.

See Nicole Barrett's article in the Columbia Human Rights Law Review.

"Holding Individual Leaders Responsible
for Violations of Customary International Law: The U.S. Bombardment of Cambodia and Laos," http://www.icai-online.org/xp_resources/barrett.pdf
That's what the Afrikaners thought of Mandela in the 1980s. But history has proven otherwise, no?  The Kurds will get their homeland.
Abdullah Ocalan's second career should be as a prisoner in his little cell to rot in jail for the rest of his life.
